trl.verification_notes: Confirmed TRL 9 - operational from Dec 2010 to Mar 2020, 22 flights to ISS. First commercial cargo spacecraft to ISS.

pressurized_volume_m3.verification_notes: Confirmed 10 m³ pressurized volume from eoPortal (ESA database)

unpressurized_volume_m3.verification_notes: Confirmed 14 m³ unpressurized trunk volume from eoPortal (ESA database)

cargo_capacity_up_kg.verification_notes: Confirmed 6000 kg payload up-mass to LEO from eoPortal

cargo_capacity_down_kg.verification_notes: Corrected from 3500 to 3000 kg per eoPortal and Orbital Velocity sources

mass_kg.verification_notes: Corrected from 12000 to 4200 kg - this is the spacecraft dry mass. Loaded missions ranged 4000-9500 kg depending on cargo.
mass_kg.notes: Spacecraft dry mass; loaded mass varies by mission

power_kw.verification_notes: Updated to 1.5 kW average (4.0 kW peak). Sources indicate >4 kW peak power from solar arrays.
power_kw.notes: 1.5 kW average, 4.0 kW peak from solar arrays on trunk

cost_usd.verification_notes: Not publicly disclosed. NASA CRS-1 contract was $1.6B for 12 flights, but per-mission costs not broken down.
cost_usd.notes: Service contract pricing not publicly disclosed per mission

items.notes: Retired in 2020, replaced by Dragon 2 Cargo. Extensive ISS heritage. Reference for lunar cargo module sizing.

trl.verification_notes: Confirmed TRL 9 - operational since Dec 2020 (CRS-21), currently active

pressurized_volume_m3.verification_notes: Corrected from 10 to 9.3 m³ per Orbital Velocity and SpaceX.com

unpressurized_volume_m3.verification_notes: Corrected from 14 to 37 m³ per Orbital Velocity and SpaceX.com

cargo_capacity_up_kg.verification_notes: Confirmed 6000 kg launch payload mass from Orbital Velocity

cargo_capacity_down_kg.verification_notes: Corrected from 3307 to 3000 kg per Orbital Velocity. Breakdown of 2507+800 kg could not be verified.

mass_kg.verification_notes: Corrected from 12519 to 9500 kg - this is the dry mass of Dragon 2 spacecraft

power_kw.verification_notes: Updated to >4 kW peak power from solar arrays integrated in trunk. Average power not specified in sources.
power_kw.notes: Peak power >4 kW from trunk-mounted solar arrays

cost_usd.verification_notes: Not publicly disclosed. NASA CRS-2 contract pricing not broken down per mission.

items.notes: Current operational cargo vehicle for ISS. Lacks crewed features (seats, life support, SuperDraco). Lunar applicability requires landing system adaptation.

trl.verification_notes: Confirmed TRL 9 - operational from Sept 2013 to 2014, 4 flights total. First flight Sept 18, 2013.

pressurized_volume_m3.verification_notes: Confirmed 18.9 m³ pressurized volume from eoPortal (ESA database)

unpressurized_volume_m3.verification_notes: Confirmed Cygnus does not have unpressurized cargo capability - pressurized module only
unpressurized_volume_m3.notes: Cygnus does not have unpressurized cargo capability

cargo_capacity_up_kg.verification_notes: Confirmed 2000 kg cargo capacity from eoPortal and Orbital Velocity

cargo_capacity_disposal_kg.verification_notes: Corrected from 8700 to 1200 kg per eoPortal. The 8700 kg figure could not be verified from any source.
cargo_capacity_disposal_kg.notes: Can dispose of trash during re-entry

mass_kg.verification_notes: Confirmed 3600 kg total spacecraft dry mass from Orbital Velocity

power_kw.verification_notes: Confirmed 3.5 kW from service module solar arrays (sun-pointed) per eoPortal. PCM uses <850W.
power_kw.notes: Solar arrays provide 3.5 kW sun-pointed; PCM allocation <850W

cost_usd.verification_notes: Not publicly disclosed. NASA CRS contract pricing not broken down per mission.

items.notes: PCM built by Thales Alenia Space. Service module based on GEOStar satellite bus. Can berth to ISS up to 75 days. Standard variant replaced by Enhanced in 2015.

trl.verification_notes: Confirmed TRL 9 - operational since 2015 (OA-4 mission), currently active

pressurized_volume_m3.verification_notes: Confirmed 27 m³ pressurized volume from eoPortal and Orbital Velocity

unpressurized_volume_m3.verification_notes: Confirmed Cygnus does not have unpressurized cargo capability - pressurized module only

cargo_capacity_up_kg.verification_notes: Confirmed 3,200-3,500 kg depending on launch vehicle per Orbital Velocity. eoPortal lists 2,700 kg, but operational missions have demonstrated up to 3,500 kg.

cargo_capacity_disposal_kg.verification_notes: Corrected from 8700 to 3750 kg per Orbital Velocity. This is disposal via destructive reentry, not return capability.

mass_kg.verification_notes: Confirmed 3600 kg total spacecraft dry mass from Orbital Velocity (1800 kg service module + PCM)

power_kw.verification_notes: Updated from null to 4.0 kW. Enhanced uses UltraFlex circular arrays providing same 4 kilowatt hours as Standard's 3.5 kW panels but with reduced mass.

cost_usd.verification_notes: Not publicly disclosed. NASA CRS contract pricing not broken down per mission.

items.notes: Increased capacity over Standard. PCM by Thales Alenia Space. Only CRS-2 provider using berthing ports.

trl.verification_notes: Confirmed TRL 9 - first flight Sept 14, 2025 (NG-23 mission), successfully berthed to ISS. Flight proven.

pressurized_volume_m3.verification_notes: Confirmed 36 m³ (1,300 cu ft) from multiple sources including Wikipedia. 15.5% increase over Enhanced (27 m³).

unpressurized_volume_m3.verification_notes: Confirmed Cygnus does not have unpressurized cargo capability - pressurized module only

cargo_capacity_up_kg.verification_notes: Confirmed 5,000 kg (11,000 lb) payload capacity from multiple sources. 33% increase over Enhanced variant.

cargo_capacity_disposal_kg.verification_notes: Corrected from 8700 to null - disposal capacity not published for XL variant. Likely similar to or greater than Enhanced (3750 kg).

mass_kg.verification_notes: Total spacecraft dry mass not published. One source mentioned ~7000 kg when loaded, but precise dry mass unconfirmed.
mass_kg.notes: Likely higher than Enhanced due to larger volume

power_kw.verification_notes: Not published. XL uses UltraFlex solar arrays like Enhanced (4 kW), but specific power output not confirmed.

cost_usd.verification_notes: Not publicly disclosed. NASA CRS contract pricing not broken down per mission.

items.notes: Largest Cygnus variant. First flight Sept 2025 (NG-23). PCM by Thales Alenia Space.

trl.verification_notes: Corrected from TRL 8 to TRL 7. Currently in final testing at KSC. First flight delayed to late 2026 and will not dock to ISS. Completed environmental, acoustic, and EMI testing.
trl.notes: First flight scheduled late 2026, currently in final testing

pressurized_volume_m3.verification_notes: Total pressurized volume with Dream Chaser is 33 m³, but breakdown between spaceplane and Shooting Star module not specified in official sources.
pressurized_volume_m3.notes: Total pressurized volume with Dream Chaser is 33 m3, breakdown not specified

unpressurized_volume_m3.verification_notes: Not published. Module has 3 external mounting points but volume not specified.

cargo_capacity_up_kg.verification_notes: Corrected from 4536 to 3629 kg (8,000 lbs) per Sierra Space official site. Combined Dream Chaser + Shooting Star system delivers up to 12,000 lbs, but the official cargo upmass specification is 8,000 lbs.
cargo_capacity_up_kg.notes: 8,000 lbs cargo upmass for Dream Chaser + Shooting Star system

cargo_capacity_up_pressurized_kg.verification_notes: Breakdown between pressurized and unpressurized not specified in official sources. System described as carrying 6+ tons of pressurized and unpressurized payloads.

cargo_capacity_up_unpressurized_kg.verification_notes: Module has 3 external mounting points, but specific unpressurized cargo capacity not published.
cargo_capacity_up_unpressurized_kg.notes: Has external mounting points but capacity not specified

cargo_capacity_disposal_kg.verification_notes: Corrected from 3250 to 3340 kg (7,365 lbs) per Sierra Space official site. Shooting Star burns up during reentry for disposal.
cargo_capacity_disposal_kg.notes: 7,365 lbs disposal capacity via Shooting Star reentry

mass_kg.verification_notes: Module mass not published in available sources.

power_kw.verification_notes: Corrected from 6 kW to null. Module provides solar arrays for combined system, but specific power output not confirmed in official sources.
power_kw.notes: Provides solar arrays but specific kW not published

dimensions_m.value: 4.6 length (15 ft), conical for fairing fit
dimensions_m.verification_notes: 4.6 m (15 ft) length confirmed from Space.com article. Conical shape for 5m payload fairing compatibility.

cost_usd.verification_notes: Not publicly disclosed. Part of NASA CRS-2 contract.

items.notes: Attaches to Dream Chaser spaceplane. Manufacturing partner: Spirit AeroSystems. Provides active/passive thermal, thrusters for translation/rotation. Expendable module for disposal.

trl.verification_notes: Confirmed TRL 9 - 239 tanks built since 1960s, flown on 150+ manned spaceflights including Apollo, Skylab, and Space Shuttle programs. Flight proven heritage.
trl.notes: 239 tanks built since 1960s, flown on 150+ manned spaceflights

heritage.verification_notes: Confirmed heritage on Apollo, Skylab, and Space Shuttle programs. Started with Gemini program in 1960s at Beech Aircraft (now Ball Aerospace).

tank_count.verification_notes: Confirmed 239 cryogen tanks and dewars built at Beech Aircraft and Ball Aerospace for cryogen storage applications.
tank_count.notes: Total tanks built at Beech Aircraft and Ball Aerospace

propellants_supported.verification_notes: Confirmed support for liquid hydrogen, liquid oxygen, liquid nitrogen, and other cryogens. Wide range of cryogen types.

mass_kg.verification_notes: Product line - varies by tank model. Specific examples exist (e.g., Space Shuttle PRSA) but individual specs not published in accessible sources.
mass_kg.notes: Varies by tank model; Space Shuttle PRSA: 335 kg O2 + 42 kg H2 capacity

volume_liters.verification_notes: Product line - varies by tank model. Wide range of volumes available but specific models not detailed in accessible sources.
volume_liters.notes: Historical example: 6000L total volume (5400L payload) for LH2 dewar

power_kw.verification_notes: Passive systems using MLI (Multi-Layer Insulation) do not require power. Active cooling systems would vary by specific application.
power_kw.notes: Passive systems (MLI) do not require power; active cooling systems vary

cost_usd.verification_notes: Not publicly disclosed. Product line pricing varies by specification.

items.notes: Extensive supercritical storage experience. Product line includes various sizes and configurations. PRSA tanks for Shuttle: 335 kg O2 at 91K, 42 kg H2 at 22K. Requires detailed specs from technical papers for specific models.

trl.verification_notes: Confirmed TRL 5-6 achieved. Testing successfully concluded in 2012 at NASA Marshall Space Flight Center. CCTD program advanced composite cryotank technology to demonstrated level.
trl.notes: Ground testing complete, TRL 5-6 range per NASA CCTD program

diameter_m.verification_notes: Confirmed 2.4 m diameter precursor tank from NASA NTRS technical report

material.verification_notes: Confirmed out-of-autoclave carbon/epoxy slit-tape tow composite construction from NASA technical report

weight_savings_percent.verification_notes: Corrected from 30% to 25% weight savings vs aluminum alloy tank per NASA technical report. 30% was cost savings.
weight_savings_percent.notes: 25% weight savings vs aluminum alloy tank

cost_savings_percent.verification_notes: Corrected from 25% to 30% cost reduction per NASA technical report

propellants_supported.verification_notes: Confirmed LH2 from testing. Tank tested with sequence of fill/drain pressure and thermal cycles using LH2.

mass_kg.verification_notes: Specific tank mass not published in accessible sources. Weight savings percentage provided but not absolute mass.

volume_liters.verification_notes: Tank volume not specified in accessible sources

power_kw.verification_notes: Passive insulation system - no power required

cost_usd.verification_notes: Not publicly disclosed. Development program, not a commercial product.

procurement_lead_time.verification_notes: Not applicable - technology demonstration program, not a commercial product

items.notes: Precursor for 5.5m demonstration tank. One-piece wall construction. Tested at Marshall Space Flight Center. Testing concluded 2012.

trl.verification_notes: Corrected from TRL 7 to TRL 6. Testing concluded in 2014 at Marshall per NASA report. Same TRL 5-6 level as 2.4m tank. Ground testing complete, focused on upper stage extended duration applications.
trl.notes: Ground testing complete, focused on upper stage extended duration applications

diameter_m.verification_notes: Confirmed 5.5 m diameter from NASA NTRS technical report

material.verification_notes: Confirmed out-of-autoclave carbon/epoxy composite construction from NASA technical report

weight_savings_percent.verification_notes: Confirmed 39% weight savings when designed to 5000 microε strain limit vs Al-Li tank
weight_savings_percent.notes: 39% weight savings when designed to 5000 microε strain limit vs Al-Li tank

sls_payload_increase_percent.verification_notes: Verified from Boeing press release - technology could increase SLS payload by 30%
sls_payload_increase_percent.notes: Technology could increase SLS payload by 30%

propellants_supported.verification_notes: Confirmed LH2 from testing per NASA report. Extended duration testing focused on liquid hydrogen storage.

design_features.value: One-piece wall, 3D reinforced y-joint, purge-able fluted core skirt

cost_usd.verification_notes: Not publicly disclosed. Development program, not a commercial product.

items.notes: Represents full-scale 8.4m SLS tank design features and strain levels. Out-of-autoclave manufacturing. Testing completed 2014 at Marshall.

trl.notes: Development phase for Artemis, TRL inferred from development status
trl.verification_notes: Confirmed TRL 5 - development phase for Artemis. $89.7M contract for in-space demonstration using liquid hydrogen.

propellants_supported.notes: Long-term storage of cryogenic hydrogen and oxygen
propellants_supported.verification_notes: Confirmed LH2, LOX support from Payload Space article

thermal_management.notes: Actively cooled during transport from LEO to Moon and on lunar surface
thermal_management.verification_notes: Confirmed active cooling from Payload Space article

configuration.verification_notes: Configuration details from Wikipedia - lower tier source

launch_vehicle.notes: Each part launched separately then docked

contract_value_usd.notes: $89.7M contract for in-space demonstration using liquid hydrogen

power_kw.notes: Active cooling requires power, amount not specified
power_kw.verification_notes: Active cooling requires power but amount not specified

items.notes: Part of Blue Origin National Team for Artemis. Reusable tug for refueling Blue Moon lander. Water-based lunar architecture vision. Artemis V mission target.

trl.notes: In production for Gateway, launch planned 2027
trl.verification_notes: Confirmed TRL 8 - in production for Gateway, launch planned 2027. Not yet flight proven.

xenon_capacity_kg.notes: Approximately 2,500 kg total, half of 5,000 kg PPE launch mass

power_kw.notes: PPE has 60 kW solar arrays but storage system power requirements not specified
power_kw.verification_notes: Storage system power requirements not specified. PPE has 60 kW total.

items.notes: Part of Gateway's Power and Propulsion Element. Feeds 48 kW electric propulsion system (7 thrusters: Busek 6kW Hall-effect + NASA AEPS). Provides 10x propellant efficiency vs chemical.

trl.notes: In development for Gateway, contract signed 2024
trl.verification_notes: Confirmed TRL 8 - in development for Gateway, contract signed 2024 per Thales official site

pressurized_features.value: Pressurized volume with 6 large windows (360° view)

cargo_capacity_kg.notes: Can carry 1.5 tonnes of cargo at launch
cargo_capacity_kg.verification_notes: Confirmed from Thales Alenia Space official press release

refueling_systems.verification_notes: Confirmed from Thales Alenia Space official press release

contract_value_eur.notes: €296M contract with ESA (includes both Lunar View and Lunar Link)
contract_value_eur.verification_notes: Confirmed from Thales Alenia Space official press release

cost_usd.verification_notes: Not publicly disclosed. Contract value is €296M total for both Lunar View and Lunar Link.

items.notes: ESPRIT = European System Providing Refueling, Infrastructure and Telecommunications. Avionics housed inside for easier maintenance. OHB: mechanical/thermal for non-pressurized parts + xenon refueling. Thales UK: chemical refueling.
